quoteFirst: I was lucky enough to get safely into Bulawayo without adventure, arriving
quoteTime: about two o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , and was not surprised to find the town under martial law. Everybody was armed, and a big laager had been formed in the market-place, where the women and children gathered when an alarm was raised.
title:
A White King in East Africa
The Remarkable Adventures of John Boyes, Trader and Soldier of Fortune, Who Became King of the Savage Wa-Kikuyu
author: Boyes, John, 1874-1951; Bulpett, C. W. L. (Charles William Lloyd), 1852-1939 [Editor]

quoteLast: , in the course of a violent storm, a fireball came down the chimney into a room in a house in the village of Salagnac (Creuse). A child and three women who were in the room suffered no harm from it.

quoteFirst: At present the air-traveller going from Paris to London spends one and a half hours covering the few miles to and from the aerodromes to the centres of the two cities and only
quoteLast: and a half hours covering the 225 miles of the air-journey. Moreover, he changes vehicles twice, at Croydon and at Le Bourget, as he does by boat and train at Dover and at Calais.
title: Aeolus; or, the future of the flying machine
author: Stewart, Oliver, Major, 1895-1976

quoteLast: there came on, without any preceding noise, a very violent shock of an earthquake. It commenced towards the north, and ran very nearly in a southerly direction. It continued nearly two minutes; everything appeared in motion. When it happened, the captain and myself were sitting reading, and we immediately ran out of the house. All the natives were down on their knees, in the middle of the streets, praying and crossing themselves.
title: Nat the Navigator. A Life of Nathaniel Bowditch. For Young Persons
author: Bowditch, Henry I. (Henry Ingersoll), 1808-1892

quoteLast: The first pitch was quickly ascended, and he then proceeded, apparently without difficulty, to the foot of the long chimney, which he passed by means of the face. On reaching the top he waved his handkerchief, and, being asked what it was like, replied that it was very stiff.
title: Climbing in The British Isles, Vol. 2 - Wales and Ireland

quoteTime: about two o'clock in the afternoon

quoteFirst: In the above experiments air was allowed to gain access to the vessels containing the broth, but if the precaution be taken of first removing the air and then exposing them to the sunshine, a very different result was obtained, for instead of the anthrax bacilli dying in from
quoteLast: and a half hours, they were found to be still alive after fifty hours' insolation. There appears, therefore, to be no doubt that sunshine in some way or other endows atmospheric oxygen with destructive power over the living protoplasm of the bacterial cells; indeed, there is considerable reason to believe that the bactericidal effect is due to the generation of peroxide of hydrogen, which is well known to possess powerfully antiseptic properties.
title: Bacteria in Daily Life
author: Frankland, Grace C., 1858-1946

quoteLast: , Scott found himself entering an ancient and dilapidated looking block in a rather disreputable part of the city.  He had fulfilled his appointment with Mr. Sutherland, and after an hour's conversation both gentlemen appeared very sanguine regarding the case under consideration.
title: That Mainwaring Affair
author: Barbour, A. Maynard (Anna Maynard), -1941
